No. A. 122, dated Simla the 18th April, 1944 To The Controller of Printing and Stationery, India SuojectAbolition of the various combinations of the Gazette of India and refixation of price of each part. _ ^ Deference your letter No. 46/22/42-A.&F., dated 29th February 1944, on the above subject. Governor General in Council approves your proposals that the existing combinations of the various parts or sections of the Gazette of India should be abolished and subscriptions for the different parts and sections recovered at the rates shown below Part of Section. Sale price Annual The rates are sanctioned for a period of 3 years, in tne first instance. Cn the expiry of this period, the position should be reviewed and a report made to this Department. location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: ‘16/59 Correspondence regarding Government of India Gazette.’

physicalDescription.extent: The file’s contents are arranged in approximate chronological order, from the earliest item at the front to the latest at the end.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 5; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 2-4; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: Correspondence relating to the reorganisation and distribution of the Gazette of India. The file contains a circular letter from the Assistant Secretary to the Government of India, dated 18 April 1944, detailing sections of the Gazetteand its sale and annual subscription prices (folio 3). The file also contains a letter from the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf to the Under Secretary to the Government of India, dated 7 June 1944, requesting certain sections of the Gazettefor distribution to the Residency, and for those offices under the administrative control of the Residency in the Persian Gulf (including Bahrain) (folio 4).
